div.p: In Part I of this paper, it was demonstrated that impulsive channel noise can be a serious detriment to the performance of directsequence spread-spectrum multiple-access (DS/SSMA) communications when conventional linear correlation reception is used. In this paper, we consider a hard-limiting correlator as an alternative for reception of multiple-access transmissions in impulsive channels. As with the previous study, we consider K asynchronous binary PSK DS/SSMA users sharing a linear channel corrupted by impulsive noise that is modeled at the output of the front-end filter of the receiver. We develop techniques for analyzing bit error probabilities of this hard-limiting receiver by exact computation for short spreading sequences, by approximation for longer spreading sequences, and by asymptotic limits for infinitely long spreading sequences. Performance is compared to that of the linear correlator under a variety of conditions, and it is seen that hard-limiting correlation reception can offer substantial improvement over conventional systems in impulsive channels. However, the linear receiver is more effective against multiple-access noise only, and so a tradeoff emerges in this problem between rejection of impulsive noise and rejection of multiple-access interference.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION N Part I of this paper
div.p: , the performance of conventional I linear DS/SSMA correlation receivers in the presence of both multiple-access interference and impulsive noise was analyzed. It was seen from this analysis that impulsive noise can seriously degrade the performance of such systems when compared to their performance on Gaussian channels, even when signal-to-noise power ratios are held constant. This indicates that the shape and not merely the variance of the noise distribution is an important factor in performance in this situation. Similar phenomena are well known in single-user communications applications [2], [5]- [7], [91, [11]-[141, [20]-[22], [26], and this problem can be corrected there by utilizing nonlinear correlators that compensate for the non-Gaussian behavior of the channel noise. One such receiver that is both simple to implement and analyze, and effective against impulsive noise is the hard-limiting correlator. In the singleuser case, this receiver outperforms the linear correlator for most impulsive noise models. Given its simplicity, it is thus preferred in the single-user case. However, in the multiuser case, there is the additional factor of performance against the multiple-access interference which must be considered, and one might expect that the use of a nonlinear receiver would result in degradation in this aspect of performance. Thus, the overall effects of impulsive and multiuser interferences on a hard-limiting correlator are not clear.

The purpose of this paper is to study the performance of hard-limiting correlation receivers for direct-sequence spread spectrum in the presence of both impulsive channel noise and multiple-access interference, and to compare this performance to that of linear correlation studied in [3]. In Section II, we present very briefly the multiple-access model of interest, we introduce the hard-limiting correlation receiver, and we discuss its performance in single-user impulsive channels. An algorithm for the computation of exact error probabilities of this hard-limiting correlator in multiuser impulsive channels is derived in Section 111, and this algorithm is used there to analyze the performance of systems featuring short spreading sequences. The algorithm is applied only t o two-user channels, since computational requirements for cases with more than two users are prohibitive. Section IV is devoted to the development of computationally efficient bounds and approximations to the bit error probabilities of hard-limiting receivers that are suitable for longer spreading sequences. Finally, in Section V, the asymptotic behavior of the hard-limiting correlator, as the length per data bit of the spreading sequences increases without bound, is examined.

As we shall see, neither of the two receivers analyzed is universally preferred. The hard-limiting correlator is more effective against the impulsive channel noise, while the linear correlator is more effective against the multiple-access noise. Thus, a tradeoff develops, the resolution of which depends on the overall noise characteristics of the channel. However, our analysis shows that, for moderate signal-to-channel-noise ratios, the beneficial effects of hard-limiting outweigh its detrimental effects for those systems considered.

div.head: PRELIMINARIES
div.p: In this section, we give a very brief description of DSI SSMA signals and state some relevant properties of this multiple-access technique (see [3]). Then, we review the method suggested in [3] for carrying out an impulsive channel assumption in this environment. Also, to gain insight into the multiuser performance of the hard-limiting correlation receiver in non-Gaussian impulsive noise, we consider briefly communications over these channels in the single-user context.

Impulsive Channel Models Since communication systems are often interfered with by noises other than the classical white Gaussian noise, it is necessary to consider other appropriate (and tractable) noise models. Therefore, in this section, we review a tractable method of studying non-Gaussian channels for correlation receivers which was introduced in Part I of this paper. This method has been used in several previous communication system analyses (see [3] for references).

In this model, the principal assumption concerning the additive, zero-mean channel noise n ( t ) is that samples 9; taken at the chip rate T,-I after front-end filtering are independent and identically distributed. This assumption is valid when the noise process is white and Gaussian. When the noise process is white but not Gaussian, with the usual lowpass filtering, the samples are uncorrelated, but not necessarily independent at the appropriate sampling rate. However, making the independence assumption is still justified in our model in view of the considerable gain in tractability this assumption yields (see also [20]). This allows us to study non-Gaussian impulsive noise sources by modeling the first-order probability distribution functions of these independent random variables.

div.head: IV. APPROXIMATE ANALYSIS OF DS/SSMA COMMUNICATIONS FOR LONG SPREADING SEQUENCES
div.p: One conclusion drawn from our hard-limiting correlation receiver analysis described in the previous section is that computing the exact expression for Pe can be very time consuming for large N. For this reason, when signature sequences of length more than 31 are used, bounds and approximations are needed to replace the exact computation of Pe. In this section, we propose an approximation, an upper bound, and a lower bound for the multiuser error probability of the hard-limiting correlation receiver in impulsive noise. The lower bound uses the idea of truncating a finite sum of positive numbers in the expression for the error probability (10); the approximation is based on estimating the probability distribution function of the test statistic Y N , and the upper bound uses a Chernoff bounding technique.

div.p: With a view toward upper bounding Pe for the hard-limiting correlation receiver, we examine the tightness of the Chernoff bound when applied to this problem. Saltzberg in [18] and Lugannani in [lo] used this method for intersymbol interference error bounding, which is similar to the problem of interest here. They found the Chernoff bound to be superior to existing upper bounds in intersymbol interference studies. However, our investigation (not reported in this paper) showed that applying the Chernoff bound to the multiuser communication system in impulsive noise with the linear correlation receiver results in a loose bound for error probability (see also [17]). For the linear case, the momentspace bounds considered in [3] are better. However, the moment-space bounding technique cannot be applied directly to the hard-limiting receiver, and so despite the possibility of achieving a loose bound, we pursue the Chernoff technique for the hard-limiting correlation receiver.

div.head: Summary
div.p: In this section, we have introduced three techniques to estimate the average error probability of the hard-limiting correlation receiver in impulsive channels. These methods were used as an alternative to the exact computation used in the previous section when N is large. The truncated-series lower bound estimated P, closely, but was computationally expensive. The binomial approximation and the Chernoff upper bound resulted in rather loose but simple estimates of the error probability of the hard-limiting correlation receiver.

Collectively, these estimation methods provided good insights into the performance of the hard-limiting correlators when N is large. From Table I1 by considering the upper and lower bounds on P,, we see that for two-user impulsive channels (e.g., E = 0.1, y 2 = loo), the performance of the hard-limiting correlation receiver improves significantly as we use longer signature sequence lengths. We explore this issue further in the following section.

div.head: VI. SUMMARY AND CONCLUSIONS
div.p: Motivated by the poor performance of linear correlation for DSISSMA reception in impulsive noise channels [3], in this paper we have studied the performance of the hard-limiting correlation receiver under the same conditions as those for which the linear correlation receiver was analyzed in [3]. We first showed that hard-limiting correlation receivers can offer significant improvement in performance over the linear correlation receiver in single-user impulsive channels. Then the combined effects of impulsive noise and multiuser interference on the performance of hard-limiting correlation receivers was compared to those on the performance of the linear correlation receiver. These results indicate that there is potential for significant improvement in performance by using hardlimiting correlation receivers in place of linear correlators for more impulsive noise channels. Moreover, the improvement becomes more visible as the length of the signature sequences used by the channel subscribers increases. We also noted that, unlike the linear correlation receiver, degradation in performance due to the interfering user is no longer uniform in a range of signal-to-noise values. In fact, as the SNR increases, the hard limiter apparently is not as effective in separating the two users as the linear correlator is. However, this deficiency is outweighed by the improvement against the impulsive noise as long as the channel noise is significant and substantially impulsive.

To gain further insight into hard-limiting correlation receivers and explore the fundamental limitation of these systems, we have also carried out an asymptotic analysis for these DSI SSMA correlation receivers. In particular, conditions have been obtained under which a multiuser system achieves asymptotic single-user error probabilities in an infinite-user environment by using infinitely long spreading sequences. Since similar conditions assure that the linear correlator also achieves single-user performance asymptotically, this limiting behavior of the probability of error together with the singleuser advantages of hard limiting reinforce the idea that the performance of the multiuser communication system operating in impulsive environments can be improved noticeably by using hard limiting.
